data.title: Former world champion Alan Jones unleashes on 'ridiculous' F1 regulations
data.meta_description: Former world champion Alan Jones has admitted he's losing interest in Formula 1, saying the sport is full of "prima donnas" and "ridiculous" regulations.
data.text:
Former world champion Alan Jones has admitted he's losing interest in Formula 1, saying the sport is full of "prima donnas" and "ridiculous" regulations.

Jones – who remains Australia's last world champion having done so in 1980 driving for Williams – said he still attends two or three grand prix events a year, but is losing interest in the sport he once conquered and is instead turning his focus to two wheels.

"I have a lot of interest now in MotoGP," he told Wide World of Sports.

"I love it, it's competitive, you don't know who's going to win the bloody race until the last lap.

"It's colourful, it's very professional … I've lost a lot of interest in Formula 1 – they're all bloody prima donnas."

He pointed to Max Verstappen's nearly $2 million license fee for 2024 as the latest example of regulations gone mad.

Drivers require a special racing licence, called a Superlicence, from the sport's governing body the FIA in order to compete in F1. But instead of just being a flat fee for all, each driver's entry fee is calculated on a base fee-plus-points-scored method.

Due to how many points the Dutchman accrued in his record-breaking 2023 campaign – a record 575 – his racing licence for the 2024 season will cost an eye-watering $1,979,702.

"$2 million for Max's licence? It's getting ridiculous," Jones said.

Jones competed in the sport between 1975 and 1986. He said he also required a Superlicence, but it came from the British Royal Automobile Club (RAC) and came at no cost.

"It just simply meant that you could drive a Formula 1 car – they didn't charge for it," he said.

"You just went into the RAC in England, filled in your form and as long as you met the requirements, you got a licence to race a Formula 1 car.

"That was it – I can't see why you have to pay $2 million for a licence. What service do they give you back for that?

"It's not like they give you some sort of special treatment or service or whatever.

"It's just a piece of paper to say that you're qualified to drive a Formula 1 car.

"It's all a bit silly."

Thankfully for Verstappen, the fee is generally not paid by the driver, but rather by the team.
